sen.j: 堺祭（さかいのまつり）は、古代・中世日本の王都・令制国郡の堺（境）で行われた祭。
sen.e: Sakai Festival (Sakai no Matsuri) is a festival that was held at corner points in Oto (imperial capital) and Koku-gun in the governing system in the ancient and medieval period of Japan.

Sakai Festival (Sakai no Matsuri) is a festival that was held at corner points and boundaries in Oto (imperial capital) and Koku-gun in the governing system in the ancient and medieval period of Japan.

sen.j: 元は村の出入口や坂・峠などで疫病や災厄を防ぎ、道の安全を祈るために堺（境）の神を祀ったのが由来とされている。
sen.e: The festival is considered originally derived from honoring to the god in Sakai to prevent plagues or disasters at doorways in a village, slope, or peak, and to pray for safety on a way.

sen.j: 律令政治の元では、神祇官が王都の境界を守る「道饗祭」を掌った。
sen.e: Under the government according to the Ritsuryo codes, Jingikan (department of workship) managed "Dokyo-sai Festival" held to protect the borders of the capital.

sen.j: だが、天平7年（735年）の疫病で大宰府管内続いて平城京で多数の死者が発生すると、諸国においても同様の祭事を行った。
sen.e: However, many people died in the area of Dazaifu and then subsequently in Heijokyo due to the plagues in 735, and as a result, similar festivals were held in various countries.

sen.j: 以後、疫病や災厄対策のために同様の祭事が増やされ、『延喜式』では内裏の外周で行う「宮城四隅疫神祭」をはじめ、外国からの賓客の入京・帰国時、行幸や斎宮下向など様々な堺祭が行われたことが記されている。
sen.e: Afterward, similar festivals have increased for prevention of plagues or disasters. "The Engisiki" describes that, when guests from foreign countries entered the capital and went back to their countries, various Sakai Festivals were held such as for gyoko (Emperor's going out) or for leaving the capital for Saigu, including "Kyujo Yosumi Ekijin-sai Festival" performed around the periphery of the dairi (Imperial Palace.)
